Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Liposomal Bupivacaine in Thoracic Surgery

Participants.evidence: 102 patients undergoing elective thoracoscopic surgery at the Affiliated Hospital of Qingdao University

Intervention.evidence: randomized 1:1 to receive thoracic paravertebral block with LB (6.67 mg/mL) or ropivacaine hydrochloride (RH; 0.33%)

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated the efficacy of liposomal bupivacaine (LB) in reducing postoperative opioid consumption and enhancing recovery in thoracic surgery patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was opioid consumption within 72 hours postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was performed using fixed block randomization with allocation concealment via sealed opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Participants, clinicians, and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between November 1, 2024, and March 10, 2025, 102 patients were randomized (LB group, n = 51; RH group, n = 51).

Number_Analysed.evidence: One patient was excluded, leaving 101 for analysis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: LB significantly reduced 72-hour opioid consumption compared to RH (mean difference = –181.4 mg; 95% CI: –232.8, –130.0 mg; P < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: No significant differences in adverse events were observed between groups.
